I get this too! I tried to describe this to my sister, and she had no idea what I was talking about. Itâ€™s just a certain â€œsomethingâ€ that you can sense when itâ€™s there and when itâ€™s not. 
This â€œsomethingâ€ feels like trying to describe the color red to someone whoâ€™s colorblind. It exist but itâ€™s just indescribable. It needs its own word. 
Idk how to keep it for a long period of time. The best thing that I could suggest is to really recognize when itâ€™s there. For example, you can scarf down a piece of chocolate cake in like 30 seconds. But if you really stop and think about the flavor and taste and smell and texture of the chocolate cake, then youâ€™ll more likely remember it and itâ€™ll probably last longer since youâ€™re taking the time to recognize it. 
Maybe this isnâ€™t what youâ€™re going through. I hope this all makes sense. Sometimes mumbo jumbo comes out of my mouth. LOL. Hope this helps.

I think the disability office looks at every case differently, but from what I recall, they didnâ€™t really ask me much about my parents. I looked on one of the websites and it says, â€œIf youâ€™re an adult and receiving SSI, then the SSA only considers your own income and other financial resources.â€ I find out tomorrow if I get disability, so I will update you then! Iâ€™ll let you know if living with someone does affect your claim.

Last month, I had a memory that I bought a $50 lottery ticket and hid it in my room (my family doesnâ€™t like me gambling, so I used to hide it from them). When I remembered that I had hidden the lottery ticket, I went into my room and started searching for it. I tore my room apart looking for it. I could not find it, but I swore that I had bought one and had hidden it behind my bed. To this day, after moving everything out of my room, I still never found it. I have been going through a manic period for a couple of months now, and stuff like this has been happening all the time. I swore I had a cat when I was a kid, but all of my family members call me crazy. I had no idea this was psychosis. Maybe I am crazy.

Iâ€™m in the same boat. I have been experiencing this feeling for the past few months, and it doesnâ€™t seem to be going away any time soon. Everything is perfect in my life, and I should be happy about it, but Iâ€™m not, and thereâ€™s no reason why I shouldnâ€™t be happy. The good moments are good, but that good feeling never lasts for some reason. The happy stuff just isnâ€™t enough. Life just tastes like stale bread. 

Iâ€™m no expert, but it sounds like you are also suffering from anhedonia (A symptom of depression). Thereâ€™s a lot of stuff on google about it. Iâ€™ve gotten some good tips from that. Iâ€™ve also just started on medication and am now going to therapy. Hopefully that stuff helps. 

People have said theyâ€™ve escaped this feeling before, so there is some hope. Good luck dude.

Sorry youâ€™re in this boat too. Itâ€™s not a good boat to be on. Itâ€™s good to know that others are able to feel the same way weâ€™re feeling right now, though. 
Itâ€™s been tough, but I do remember some of my good moments. I remember I used to feel good all the time a few years ago, but Iâ€™m not sure where that feeling went. I have completely forgotten how to feel any pleasure. I guess my problem is that I have never gotten out of anhedonia land before, so Iâ€™m not sure how to even start to escape. Iâ€™ve been feeling this way so long that I donâ€™t even know if itâ€™s worth it to try and get out. How did you get out the first time?

I was kind of in the same situation as you. In college I started falling behind because of my depression, and all my responsibilities kept building as I tried to cope with my problems. It all became too much. I was going to drop out, but I couldnâ€™t afford it. The scholarship that I have wouldnâ€™t be awarded to me again if I decided to re enroll after dropping out. So my counselor told me to take a medical leave instead. Idk how your university works, but maybe talk to someone about a medical leave. If you take one you, then you can go home and get all your ducks in order, and then you can return to uni feeling ready and confident in yourself and your studies. 
This is what Iâ€™m doing right now, and itâ€™s really relieving. I can work on my mental health without the pressures of school and friends. I wish I had done this sooner. Taking care of yourself is more important than I had initially thought. 

Good luck bud, and I hope everything works out for you!

Edit: On my medical leave I got a refund for the tuition I had paid.
